Cu/ZnO and Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 catalysts used for methanol steam reforming S.G. Sanches J. Huertas Flores M.I. Pais da Silva ⁎ Departamento de Química, Pontifícia Universidade Católica de Rio de Janeiro, Rua Marquês de São Vicente 225, Gávea, Rio de Janeiro, CEP 22453-900, Brazil Departamento de Química Pontifícia Universidade Católica de Rio de Janeiro Rua Marquês de São Vicente 225 Gávea Rio de Janeiro CEP 22453-900 Brazil ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Cu/ZnO and Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 catalysts were prepared by co-precipitation method and used in methanol steam reforming at 250 °C. The catalysts were characterized by N2 adsorption, X-ray diffraction (XRD), temperature-programmed reduction (TPR), H2 temperature-programmed desorption (H2-TPD), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS). ZrO2 affect the textural, structural and morphological properties of the CuO/ZnO catalyst. ZrO2 nanoclusters or amorphous material was found in Zr-based catalyst which role was to prevent the CuO and ZnO crystallite growth causing a microstrain in Cu and Zn oxides lattice. This effect facilitated the formation of exposed CuO species, which were easier to reduce and favored the catalytic performance of Zr-based catalyst. Monoclinic ZrO2 found in Zr-based catalyst decrease the CO formation deeply because of the higher capacity of monoclinical ZrO2 to adsorbed CO. The Cu2O active site found in CuO/ZnO catalyst was not more efficient than active sites in Zr-based catalyst. The results confirmed that the interactions between Cu and ZnO/ZrO2 were different from those between Cu and ZnO. Keywords Cu/Zn/Zr catalyst Methanol steam reforming XANES EXAFS Hydrogen production 1 Introduction Hydrogen is an important chemical that can be produced from coal and hydrocarbons. Recently, hydrogen has also been utilized as a fuel cell energy source. However, hydrogen is not readily portable. One solution to this problem is on-board hydrogen processing from a liquid source such as methanol, dimethyl ether or gasoline [1]. Hydrogen can be produced from methanol steam reforming over ZnO-supported copper catalysts at relatively low temperatures; however, the concentration of the CO intermediate must be less than 10 ppm because it poisons catalytic fuel cell anodes [2]. Copper catalysts are also used frequently to methanol production from H2/CO2 and the methanol may be transformed in dimethyl ether using an acid component as zeolite, [3–5]. Copper catalysts are often prepared by co-precipitation [6] because Cu particles can be dispersed among promoter and/or stabilizer particles, such as metal oxides [7]. In a typical co-precipitation procedure, hydroxycarbonated precursors are used to produce Cu-based catalysts [8], because they enable Cu atom dispersion within the matrix of another metal, such as Zn or Al. Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 is a conventional co‐precipitated catalyst used in the synthesis and steam reforming of methanol [9–11]. Cu/ZnO catalysts for methanol steam reforming have also been extensively studied and exhibit high activity in this reaction [12–14]. The Cu/ZnO catalyst precursor aurichalcite has a complex sheet structure with a 3:2 octahedral:tetrahedral site ratio for divalent cations. Catalysts prepared from aurichalcite-rich precursors generally exhibit high activity and selectivity in methanol synthesis [15]. Aurichalcite is formed when the Cu/Zn molar ratio is 50/50 or 30/70 [15]. Fujitani and Nakamura [16] concluded that “methanol is mainly produced over the catalyst prepared from aurichalcite.” The active sites of these catalysts were investigated in several studies [12–14,17–20]. The nature of the Cu–ZnO interactions in the catalyst was described in one report [20]. In another study, it was proposed that Cu is incorporated into the ZnO phase at interstitial and substitutional sites [21]. Other researchers speculated that formate ions adsorbed on Cu0 are hydrogenated via hydrogen spillover from ZnO, which acts as an atomic hydrogen reservoir [22,23]. Furthermore, Cu-Zn alloy formation on the surface might occur by ZnO migration to the Cu0 crystallites [13,24]. In contrast, it was suggested that Cu0 and ZnO do not act synergistically during the catalytic reaction; Cu0 is catalytically active, whereas ZnO simply stabilizes the Cu particles [25]. Zirconium promoter is very used in CuO/ZnO based catalyst, [3–5]. Adding zirconium to Cu-based catalysts during co-precipitation results in the formation of highly dispersed Cu and ZnO particles, which improves their activity in methanol steam reforming [17,18]. It is known that Zr inhibits ZnO particle growth, but its role in the catalytic system appears to be broader; structural changes were observed in Cu/ZnO catalysts when Zr was added as a promoter [1,17,18]. Some researchers proposed that Zr enhances the interactions between the Cu and ZnO particles [1,19]. Indeed, sintering is suppressed by the presence of small ZrO2 particles [1]. Oguchi et al. [26] demonstrated that ZrO2 favors the formation of Cu2O, which is directly involved in the catalytic reaction. It was studied the CuO/ZnO and CuO/ZnO/ZrO2 catalysts prepared by coprecipitation having the aurichalcite phase as precursor and they were tested in methanol stem reforming reaction to produce hydrogen. It was studied the effects of the Zr promoter on the structural, textural and morphological properties of Cu/ZnO-based catalysts. It was verified as the Zr influenced over the catalytic performance of the CuO/ZnO catalyst. 2 Experimental procedure 2.1 Catalyst preparation Cu/Zn and Cu/Zn/Zr catalysts were prepared by conventional co-precipitation at a constant pH. Metal nitrate (1.0 M) and sodium carbonate (1.2 M) solutions were slowly and simultaneously added to 100 mL of deionized water at 70 °C and pH 7 ± 0.5 under vigorous stirring. After the reactants were consumed, the precipitate was aged for 1 h at 70 °C under stirring. Then, the solid was washed with 1 L of water at 70 °C to eliminate the Na and nitrate residues. The precipitate was dried at 80 °C for 12 h and then calcined by heating to 400 °C at a rate of 5 °C min−1 under an N2 flow (50 mL min−1). The binary and ternary catalysts were prepared using Cu/Zn and Cu/Zn/Zr molar ratios of 40/60 and 15/50/35, respectively, and were denoted CZ and CZZ, respectively. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The chemical compositions of the catalysts were determined by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) using a Perkin-Elmer Optima 4300 DV instrument. Before analysis, the samples were dissolved in nitric and hydrochloric acids. The textural properties were determined by N2 adsorption at −196 °C using an ASAP 2010 Micromeritics instrument. Before analysis, the samples were degassed at 300 °C under vacuum. The uncalcined, calcined and reduced samples were analyzed by X-ray diffraction (XRD) using a Rigaku Miniflex X-ray diffractometer and Cu Kα radiation (λ  = 0.1541 nm). The patterns were collected over a 2θ range of 10–60°. The samples were reduced at 250 °C for 1 h using pure H2 gas. Then, the samples were exposed to 5% O2 in He at room temperature for 1 h to stabilize the Cu surface and prevent bulk oxidation before the XRD analysis. The copper surface area was determined by H2 temperature‐programmed desorption (H2-TPD) in a conventional TPD apparatus coupled to a Balzers quadrupole mass spectrometer. The procedure was adapted from Mühler et al. [27]. The samples were dried in pure He at 150 °C for 1 h and then reduced with pure H2 (60 mL min−1) under heating to 250 °C at a rate of 10 °C min−1 over 1 h (same reaction conditions). After reduction, the samples were cooled in an ice bath at 0 °C for 1 h and then in a liquid nitrogen bath (−196 °C) for an additional hour. He gas was subsequently flowed over the samples at a rate of 50 mL min−1 at liquid nitrogen temperature for 30 min to eliminate physically adsorbed H2. Finally, the samples were removed from the bath and heated to 350 °C. Hydrogen desorption was monitored during heating by the m/z = 2 fragment. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) was performed in a conventional TPR instrument. In a typical experiment, the sample was placed in a quartz reactor and dried with argon gas at 150 °C for 30 min. Then, the sample was reduced in 1.56% H2 in Ar (50 mL min−1) under heating at a rate of 10 °C min−1. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were obtained using a JEOL 2010 microscope operating at 200 kV with a CCD camera. The samples were studied in situ by XANES at the Cu and Zr K-edges. The experiments were performed in transmission mode at the D06-DXAS beamline at the Brazilian Synchrotron Light Laboratory (LNLS) using synchrotron radiation produced by a 1.37 GeV electron storage ring with a maximum current of 200 mA. Fifty mg sample pellets were mounted in a stainless steel holder placed in the center of a temperature-controlled flow reactor cell, through which a reactant or inert gas was flowed. The closed-end quartz tube reactor had aluminum flanges sealed by Kapton® windows and was heated by a halogen lamp furnace. The XANES spectra were recorded as 5 mol% H2 in He was flowed through the reactor at a rate of 55 mL min−1. During the experiments, the sample was heated from 25 °C to 250 °C at a rate of 10 °C min−1 and then kept at 250 °C for 30 min. Before the experiments, the reactor was purged with He (30 mL min−1) for 30 min. The gas flow was regulated by individual mass flow controllers. The EXAFS spectra were collected at the D04B-XAFS1 beamline at LNLS. This bending magnetic beamline is equipped with a (111) silicon channel‐cut monochromator. The spectra of the calcined and reduced samples were obtained at room temperature and 250 °C, respectively. The EXAFS analysis was performed using the Athena/Artemis software package (FEFF version 6.0). During the data fitting, the passive electron amplitude reduction factor (S02) was set to the same value as that for the reference compounds. 2.3 Catalytic activity tests The catalytic activity tests were performed in a continuous-flow fixed-bed reactor at 250 °C and atmospheric pressure. First, the samples (250 mg) were reduced with pure H2 (60 mL min−1) at the reaction temperature for 1 h. Then, water and methanol were introduced into the reactor in an H2O/CH3OH molar ratio of 3 using N2 as the carrier gas (90 mL min−1). The products were analyzed using a Balzers Quadstar™ 422 QMS 200 mass spectrometer. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Chemical composition and textural properties The Cu/Zn and Cu/Zn/Zr molar ratios of the CZ and CZZ catalysts, respectively, were very close to the expected values (Table 1 ). Aurichalcite formation is favored by the Cu/Zn molar ratio of 40/60 used in the synthesis procedure. The Zr content of the CZZ sample demonstrated that large amounts of Zr can be introduced into Cu-based catalysts by conventional co-precipitation. Zr incorporation into the Cu-based catalyst resulted in a considerable increase in the specific area and slight decrease in the pore volume (Table 1). Both samples exhibited Type IV isotherms, which are characteristic of mesoporous materials (Fig. 1 ). For the CZ catalyst, very little hysteresis was observed between the adsorption and desorption branches, which were essentially vertical at ca. 0.98 P/P0 due to adsorption in the spaces between uniform spherical particles. In contrast, greater hysteresis between the adsorption and desorption branches was observed in the CZZ isotherm, which was attributed to adsorption in the spaces between non-uniformly sized particles (Fig. 1). The CZZ sample also had a smaller adsorption capacity and cumulative pore volume than CZ, likely due to a decrease in the interparticle space or particle size in the presence of Zr [28]. The pore size distributions are also presented in (Fig. 1). The CZ sample had uniform mesopores (ca. 30 Å), whereas the CZZ sample had a bimodal pore size distribution, demonstrating that the pore sizes and hence the particle sizes were non-uniform. Specifically, the CZZ sample had pores of approximately 30 Å and 150 Å. These results showed that Zr incorporation into the catalyst resulted in changes in the textural properties, probably due to the formation of particles with non-uniform sizes or irregular shapes. 3.2 Structural characteristics The XRD patterns of the uncalcined samples are presented in Fig. 2 (a). Intense peaks corresponding to the aurichalcite precursor phase were observed in the CZ pattern. Aurichalcite peaks were also observed in the CZZ pattern; however, their intensities were much lower. This decrease in the peak intensities was attributed to a decrease in the crystallinity upon Zr incorporation into the catalyst. A high Zn content or a Cu:Zn molar ratio of approximately 1:2 favors aurichalcite formation [29]. A low Zn content can lead to the formation of malachite or zincian malachite phases, and a high copper concentration can give rise to phases such as malachite and rosasite. Indeed, Cu and Zn ions precipitate under different conditions, even in conventional precipitation processes; therefore, different phases, such as malachite, zincian malachite or even zincite, can form [30]. Precipitation at a constant pH might prevent Cu and Zn hydrolytic limitations that cause these ions to precipitate under different conditions. Therefore, the synthesis conditions for the Cu/Zn-based catalyst used in this study should lead to aurichalcite formation. Few transition metal ions can substitute into the aurichalcite lattice; however, the precursor phase formed during the synthesis was unaffected by the large amount of Zr introduced into the structure. Shen et al. [29] reported that Zn2+ does not isomorphically substitute for Cu2+. Therefore, it is unlikely that Zr substituted for Cu2+ or Zn2+, and the broader peaks in the CZZ XRD pattern might have been due to an increase in the metal-oxygen bond covalency or to distortion of the octahedral geometry of the metal atoms in the presence of Zr. These effects might have reduced the aurichalcite phase crystallinity. After calcination, peaks corresponding to oxidized Cu and Zn phases were observed in the XRD patterns (Fig. 2(b)). As observed for the uncalcined samples, the CuO and ZnO peaks were more intense for CZ than for CZZ. The weaker Cu and Zn oxide peaks observed in the CZZ pattern revealed the presence of smaller, isolated oxide crystallites. No ZrO2 peaks were observed for the CZZ catalyst. The decreases in the peak intensities observed for the CZZ sample showed that the structural changes due to Zr incorporation into the catalyst were still present after aurichalcite oxidation. According to Matsumura et al. [31], amorphous ZrO2 is generally undetectable by XRD. The absence of ZrO2 peaks in the CZZ XRD pattern after calcination (Fig. 2(b)) indicated that highly dispersed, amorphous ZrO2 particles or ZrO2 nanoclusters were probably present. The samples also underwent structural changes during reduction. Peaks corresponding to metallic Cu were observed in the binary and ternary samples, confirming the reduction of Cu+2 to Cu0 (Fig. 2(c)). After reduction, the ZnO peaks became more obvious. The CZ sample exhibited more intense peaks than the CZZ sample due to the structural changes caused by Zr incorporation. Furthermore, ZrO2 peaks were not observed after reduction. The higher crystalline CuO content in the calcined CZ sample, as determined by Rietveld refinement (Table 2 ), might be due to partial segregation of the ZnO phase during calcination. This behavior was not observed in the CZZ sample. The structural differences between the CZ and CZZ samples were confirmed by the Rietveld refinement results. Introducing Zr into the catalyst resulted in an increase in the CuO and ZnO phase microstrains. This increase was more pronounced for the ZnO phase. Furthermore, the CuO and ZnO crystallite sizes decreased upon Zr incorporation, and the decrease was larger for ZnO. These results indicate that Zr probably limits CuO and ZnO crystallite growth by acting as a buffer. The Zr promoter also caused structural changes to the Cu phase in the reduced sample. In particular, the Cu phase microstrain was smaller for the CZZ sample than for the CZ sample, indicating that the reduced Cu content was higher in CZZ. The Cu lattice constants of the CZ and CZZ samples were larger than that of the standard pure Cu phase (a = 3.616 Å). For the CZ sample, this result might be attributed to differences in the Zn-Cu interactions caused by the catalyst precursor [16] or to ZnO nanocluster formation in the CuO framework. For the CZZ sample, the increase in the Cu lattice constant was mainly due to Zr incorporation into the structure. In summary, Zr incorporation into the Cu/Zn-based catalyst led to structural changes, namely, decreases in the microstrain and crystallite size and an increase in the lattice constant. The exact nature of the Zr effects on the structural properties of the Cu/Zn-based catalyst is not well understood, but they might be related to Zr incorporation into the CuO or ZnO lattice as an isolated species or to the formation of highly dispersed ZrO2 nanoclusters among the CuO and ZnO phases. 3.3 Temperature-programmed reduction The CZ sample exhibited one reduction peak, whereas the CZZ sample exhibited an asymmetric peak with a low-temperature shoulder peak (Fig. 3 ). Moreover, the reduction temperatures of the CZZ sample were lower than that of the CZ sample. The differences between the reduction profiles are clearly related to the Zr promoter [29,30,32,33]. The decrease in the reduction temperature due to Zr incorporation might be attributed to a higher Cu dispersion facilitated by Zr. The symmetric reduction profile for the CZ sample was attributed to the uniform Cu2+ species distribution, as indicated by the uniform particle size distribution. In contrast, the broad, asymmetric reduction peaks of the CZZ sample were due to the reduction of different Cu2+ species. The low-temperature shoulder might be attributed to the reduction of small CuO particles or clusters or a CuO phase with Zr impurities. The high-temperature reduction peak was attributed to the reduction of a pure, crystalline CuO phase [34] or large particles, which led to a sharp decrease in the hydrogen consumption signal and thus an asymmetric reduction profile. In summary, the uniform particles in the CZ sample resulted in one reduction peak, whereas the CZZ sample was composed of non-uniform particles and therefore exhibited a more complex reduction profile. These results are in agreement with the textural analysis (Fig. 1). 3.4 TEM results To study the effects of Zr on the CZ catalyst morphology, TEM images of the CZ and CZZ samples were obtained. Agglomerated particles with regular morphologies and uniform particle sizes (ca. 25 nm) were observed in the CZ sample, in accordance with the textural analysis. The selected area diffraction pattern in the inset in Fig. 4 (a) showed diffraction spots in an approximately circular format indicated the formation of a polycrystalline material (Fig. 4(a)). These results are consistent with the XRD results. The Zr-promoted sample consisted of aggregated particles with a different morphology (Fig. 4(b)). The particles in CZZ sample were smaller (ca. 10 nm) than the observed in CZ sample and furthermore, they did not shown regular morphology. These results are consistent with the XRD and textural property results. Amorphous material was also observed in CZZ sample (Fig. 4(b)). These particular behavior, non-crystalline parts of the particles agglomerates was also found by Matsumura et al. [31]. The diffraction rings in the selected area diffraction pattern in the inset in Fig. 4(b) showed diffraction spots in ring shape characteristics of nanocrystalline materials. This result is consistent with the XRD results and indicated that Zr facilitated the formation of highly dispersed particles. 3.5 Cu K-edge X-ray absorption spectroscopy The normalized XANES spectra of the CZ and CZZ samples before and after reduction in hydrogen are plotted in Fig. 5 with those of the reduced copper (Cu0), Cu2O and CuO references. A strong intense white line (WL) at ca. 8997 eV was observed for the calcined samples and CuO reference (Fig. 5A). Therefore, it was attributed to the Cu(II) 1 s → 4pxy electron transition. These results are in agreement with those of Sato et al. [35]. The Cu absorption edge appeared at 8979.4 eV, whereas the Cu metal foil exhibited an absorption edge at 8978.3 eV and a well-resolved doublet in the post-edge region. After reduction, the XANES spectra of both samples changed considerably. A shoulder peak appeared at approximately 8981 eV, and the WL due to the 1 s → 4pxy electron transition disappeared, indicating that Cu0 was the dominant species in the reduced samples. Furthermore, the reduced samples exhibited edge features similar to that of the Cu foil reference, and a well-resolved doublet in the post-edge region (8990–9000 keV), which is characteristic of Cu0, was also observed for both samples, although it was significantly lower in amplitude than the reference doublet. The amplitude of the CZZ spectrum was lower than that of the CZ spectrum, due to some disorder in the Cu structure and/or very small particle sizes [36]. Under a typical hydrogen flow, CuO is transformed into Cu2O, which is then reduced to Cu without proceeding through a well-ordered intermediate phase. Therefore, amorphous CuO phases might have been present in these systems. The reduction processes of CZ and CZZ were studied by time-resolved XANES/EXAFS (Figs. 6 and 7 ). Significant changes in the near-edge region were observed during CuO and Cu2O reduction between 150 and 200 °C. Based on visual inspection of the XANES data, the CZZ sample was reduced at a lower temperature than the CZ sample [37]. The Fourier transforms (FTs) of the Cu K-edge EXAFS spectra and their fits for the CZ and CZZ reduced samples are presented in Fig. 8 . For both samples, the FT spectra were well fitted by a copper model structure in which the copper nearest neighbors and next nearest neighbors are oxygen and copper, respectively. The Cu–O shoulder in the fitted spectra was more intense for CZ than for CZZ [19]. The coordination number (CN), the distances (R) between neighboring atoms and the σ2 values are listed in Table 3 . In the reduced CZ and CZZ samples, the Cu-O bond lengths were 1.811 Å and 1.866 Å, respectively, which correspond to the Cu-O first shell in Cu2O [38]. The Cu-O distance of 1.951 Å in CZ was attributed to CuO phases. However, the low coordination number indicated that very little Cu2O- and CuO-like bonding occurred in this system. In addition, Cu–Cu distances of 2.541 and 2.516 Å were observed for CZ and CZZ, respectively [39]. The results showed that the amount of metallic copper formed during reduction was higher in the CZZ catalyst than in the CZ catalyst (the CZZ Cu–Cu coordination number was higher). Cu-ZrO2 interactions were not observed by in situ EXAFS spectroscopy after reduction. The low Cu–Cu coordination number in the CZ sample demonstrated that Cu was partially oxidized after the activation process. More CuO was reduced in the presence of Zr than in its absence under the same activation conditions. The strongly disordered structure and/or small crystallite sizes of the nanostructured CuO-ZnO-ZrO2 in the CZZ sample led to the observed differences in the Cu-O and Cu–Cu shell amplitudes in the CZ and CZZ FT (χ(k)k3) spectra (Fig. 8) [39]. Okamoto et al. [40] proposed that highly dispersed Cu2+ ions were present in CuO/ZrO2 to account for deviations from the ideal CuO structure observed in the FT (χ(k)) spectra. However, the results of this study did not support this conclusion. 3.6 Zr K-edge X-ray absorption spectroscopy Fig. 9 shows the Zr K-edge spectra of pure ZrO2 and the CZZ sample. The pure ZrO2 and CZZ spectra exhibited similar sharp white line features, indicating the presence of monoclinic ZrO2 in CZZ [41]. The white line peak of pure ZrO2 was more intense than that of CZZ, but both samples exhibited one similar pre-edge feature (see arrow in Fig. 9(a)). As noted by Grunwaldt et al. [42], the pre-edge peak is due to electronic transitions to unoccupied high-energy states near the Fermi level and is sensitive to the local symmetry of the probed element (Fig. 9(a)). Clearly, the Zr K-edge white line spectral features of pure ZrO2 were very similar to those of the CZZ sample. The local atomic structure (monoclinic/tetragonal) of the compounds was determined based on the work of Oguchi et al. [26], in which the spectral features of CuO/ZrO2 were compared to those of the standard monoclinic and tetragonal zirconia phases and found to be very similar to those of monoclinic zirconia. To further understand the Zr local atomic structure in the pure oxide and CZZ sample, EXAFS analysis was performed at the Zr K-edge. The Zr K-edge EXAFS spectra were processed using the Athena/Artemis software package. The spectra were Fourier transformed into real space (r-space) to determine the relative bond lengths and local atomic structure around the absorbing atom. The r-space data were fitted in the range of 1–5 Å. A comparison of the FT k3-weighted χ(k) spectra of pure ZrO2 and the CZZ sample is shown in Fig. 9(b). An intense peak attributed to the Zr-O first shell was observed for pure ZrO2. A second peak that was lower in intensity was observed for both samples and attributed to the Zr–Zr second shell. Fig. 9(c) shows the fitted EXAFS results for both samples. As previously mentioned, the first and second shells in the FT-EXAFS spectra are due to the single cation-oxygen and cation–cation scattering paths, respectively. The results in Table 3 showed that the pure ZrO2 sample exhibited bond distances and coordination numbers that were very similar to those of bulk ZrO2 [43]. For the CZZ sample, the intensities of the Zr-O and Zr–Zr peaks were lower, indicating poor Zr-O or Zr–Zr bonding or a nearly amorphous structure. Foraita et al. [44] found that the Zr-O and Zr–Zr bond lengths in tetragonal ZrO2 are longer (shifted to the right in the FT-EXAFS spectrum) than those in monoclinic ZrO2. The CZZ FT-EXAFS spectrum is shown in Fig. 9(b). The first peaks of both ZrO2 and CZZ appeared at the same distance, indicating that they were monoclinic and had similar local atomic structures. However, the Zr-O and Zr–Zr coordination numbers in the CZZ sample were lower than those in ZrO2, indicating that ZrO2 was present as an amorphous material in CZZ. 3.7 Catalytic activity The CZZ sample exhibited a higher methanol conversion than the CZ sample (Table 4 ). The activity results were consistent with the measured Cu surface areas, i.e., the CZZ sample also had a higher Cu surface area than the CZ sample (Table 4). The Zr promoter facilitated an increase in the Cu surface area and H2 production and a significant decrease in the CO yield. It is known that metallic Cu acts as an active site for methanol steam reforming [45]. The CZZ catalyst exhibited a highest H2 production compared to CZ catalyst, Table 4. The CZ catalyst presented CO production due to water gas-shift reaction. No amounts of CO were observed in CZZ catalyst. This low CO production on ZrO2-based catalyst was attributed to monoclinic ZrO2 because the water gas-shift is not favored over this phase [46]. It was demonstrated by Águila et al. [46] that bulk CuO are the active sites in water gas-shift when supported on tetragonal ZrO2. There is a higher capacity of the monoclinic Cu/ZrO2 catalyst to adsorb CO. The larger capacity of the monoclinic Cu/ZrO2 to adsorb CO leads to a higher formation of formates, which are then hydrogenated to form methanol [47]. Both catalysts have not the same Cu content. To verified the real H2 production bu Cu amount, the mol produced was divided per gram of Cu as shown in Table 4. It is very evident that the catalytic performance of CuO/ZnO/ZrO2 catalyst was very enhanced, meanwhile, in this study was not verified the effect of Zr over the catalytic stability and not results about this are shown here. The high catalytic activity of the Zr-promoted sample might be related to the structural changes to the catalyst upon Zr incorporation. No evidence of the formation of new active sites was observed. Nakamura et al. [48,49] reported the formation of a Cu-Zn alloy upon the incorporation of Zn species into the Cu framework in Cu-Zn-based materials with higher Zn contents. Zn incorporation resulted in an increase in the Cu lattice constant, and the observed increase in the catalytic activity was attributed to the presence of the Cu-Zn alloy. However, in this study, the larger Cu lattice constant of the CZZ sample was not related to Cu-Zn alloy formation, but to the presence of Zr within the lattice, i.e., the formation of isolated ZrO2 particles among the Cu and ZnO particles. Other researchers also observed that adding Zr significantly increases the Cu surface area [31]. In this study, the ZrO2 particles in the catalyst were amorphous-like as revealed by the Zr K-edge EXAFS fitting results. This amorphous-like material might consisted of very small ZrO2 aggregates that were highly dispersed in the oxide mixture and thus limited the CuO and ZnO crystallite growth, as indicated by the TEM images and XRD results. Small CuO crystallites are easily reduced at low temperatures and therefore have higher activities. Two reduction peaks are often observed for Cu-based catalysts supported on ZnO and/or ZrO2 [33,45–48]. The peak positions depend on the CuO particle size. Small particles are reduced at low temperatures [50–53]. The CuO reduction temperature decreases with increasing ZnO content when the ZnO content is low and remains fairly constant when the ZnO content is high [51]. Kurr et al. [10] confirmed that highly exposed CuO particles are easily reduced and asserted that the high-temperature reduction peak is due to the reduction of CuO particles that are partially covered with other oxide particles [54,55]. These CuO particles are mainly encapsulated in aggregates that form during catalyst preparation. In this study, Zr promoted oxide reduction in the CuO-ZnO sample by facilitating the formation of highly exposed CuO particles. Günter et al. [12] reported that Cu2O forms during the initial CuO/ZnO reduction stage, suggesting that the exposed CuO particles that are beneficial for the catalytic activity are partially reduced to Cu2O [1]. The EXAFS results showed that the CZ sample had traces of Cu2O and CuO; however, its catalytic activity was lower than that of the CZZ sample. A decrease in the reduction temperature was attributed to the formation of more exposed CuO sites. It was also suggested that structurally disordered Cu particles have higher catalytic activities in methanol steam reforming [56]. The structural disorder influences the surface interactions between the Cu and ZnO particles, and the particle sizes and morphologies affect the catalytic activity. The Zr-promoted sample had a non-uniform surface structure, and the incorporated Zr might have facilitated higher contact between the Cu and ZnO particles. Because the ZrO2-rich domains were present on the aggregate surfaces, it was concluded that the majority of the Cu and ZnO particles in these domains had more exposed areas. The higher reducibility of Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 and the small degree of microstrain in the copper particles in the CZZ sample strongly indicated that the metal-support interactions between Cu and ZrO2 were different from those between Cu and ZnO. 4 Conclusions CuO/ZnO and CuO/ZnO/ZrO2 catalysts were prepared by conventional co-precipitation and tested in methanol steam reforming reaction. The precursor phase formed was the aurichalcite, even in catalyst based on Zr, introduced during the co-precipitation. The Zr introduction produced important changes on the structural, textural and morphological properties on the CuO/ZnO catalyst. The results demonstrated that the zirconium is presented as amorphous-like species and distorts the octahedral lattice aurichalcite geometry. The presence of zirconium increased the CuO and ZnO microstrain decreasing their crystallite size and limiting their growth. This behavior had a correlation with the reduction temperature. Zr-based sample showed is reduced at lower temperature and a higher amount of metallic Cu was formed during the reduction in Zr-based catalyst. The low CO production in Zr-based catalyst was identified by the monoclinic structure of ZrO2 present in CZZ sample. Cu2O phase found after calcination of CuO/ZnO catalyst was not more active than the metallic Cu found in higher measure in CuO/ZnO/ZrO2. coredata.dc:description: Cu/ZnO and Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 catalysts were prepared by co-precipitation method and used in methanol steam reforming at 250 °C. The catalysts were characterized by N2 adsorption, X-ray diffraction (XRD), temperature-programmed reduction (TPR), H2 temperature-programmed desorption (H2-TPD), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS). ZrO2 affect the textural, structural and morphological properties of the CuO/ZnO catalyst. ZrO2 nanoclusters or amorphous material was found in Zr-based catalyst which role was to prevent the CuO and ZnO crystallite growth causing a microstrain in Cu and Zn oxides lattice. This effect facilitated the formation of exposed CuO species, which were easier to reduce and favored the catalytic performance of Zr-based catalyst. Monoclinic ZrO2 found in Zr-based catalyst decrease the CO formation deeply because of the higher capacity of monoclinical ZrO2 to adsorbed CO. The Cu2O active site found in CuO/ZnO catalyst was not more efficient than active sites in Zr-based catalyst. The results confirmed that the interactions between Cu and ZnO/ZrO2 were different from those between Cu and ZnO.
coredata.dc:title: Cu/ZnO and Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 catalysts used for methanol steam reforming
